_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Safety Administration (OSHA) Process Safety Management (PSM) standards and the Maritime Transportation Security Act (MTSA).
The anhydrous ammonia product is stored in refrigerated liquid form at near atmospheric pressure in an insulated tank, which has double walls for improved mechanical integrity. Both walls allow for the containment of the full capacity of liquid ammonia. This” tank-within-a-tank” design greatly reduces the probability of a potential leak.
The anhydrous ammonia storage tank is equipped with automatic shut-off and relief devices have been installed to handle fluctuations in temperature and pressure. Warning alarms, leak detectors, regular equipment inspections, and pressure monitoring in pipes and vessels provide layers of protection for employees and the community.

Five Year Accident History:
The anhydrous ammonia storage is new and therefore has not had any releases of anhydrous ammonia over the past five years which meet the reporting criteria.

Emergency Response Program:
Emergency response programs are in place for both internal preparation and coordination with the community. The Facility is coordinating with the Local Emergency Planning Committee to ensure community safety. Drills are coordinated with the community and the community warning sirens are tested weekly.

Planned Changes to Improve Safety:
Facility processes will be routinely changed to improve safety as a result of employee suggestions, process hazard analyses, and incident investigations. All changes will be controlled and reviewed through a management of change process to ensure that they are safe.
